title: Double slit - angle for constructive interference

content.question: The figure shows a close-up view of two closely-spaced slits separated by a distance <math alttext="d" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>d</mi></math>. A beam of light of wavelength <math alttext="lambda" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>λ</mi></math> is incident on the slits from the left. The two dashed lines indicate possible paths for light emerging from the slits and meeting at a common point on a distant screen (not shown). The two paths are nearly parallel, and can be considered to be at the same angle <math alttext="theta" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>θ</mi></math> from the original beam direction. If the two paths meet at a brightness maximum in the interference pattern formed on the screen, which of the following is a possible expression for <math alttext="theta" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>θ</mi></math>?

choices.label: <math alttext="the inverse sine of the fraction with numerator 2 lambda, and denominator d, end fraction" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msup><mi>sin</mi><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mfrac><mrow><mn>2</mn><mi>λ</mi></mrow><mi>d</mi></mfrac><mo>)</mo></mrow></math>

<math alttext="the inverse sine of the fraction with numerator lambda, and denominator 2 d, end fraction" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msup><mi>sin</mi><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mfrac><mi>λ</mi><mrow><mn>2</mn><mi>d</mi></mrow></mfrac><mo>)</mo></mrow></math>

<math alttext="the inverse tangent of the fraction with numerator 2 lambda, and denominator d, end fraction" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msup><mi>tan</mi><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mfrac><mrow><mn>2</mn><mi>λ</mi></mrow><mi>d</mi></mfrac><mo>)</mo></mrow></math>
